Description:
This manuscript contains the mantras used in the "Khvk Sai Pha". In this puja Lengdon is the main God worshipped including Khao Kham, Ai Lengdin, Jan Sai Hung, Ja Sing Pha, Chit Lam Sam, Ra Khin and Ba Khin. Further, if this ritual is done in a social manner it is called Om Pha puja and if it is done within a family it is called Sai Pha. Fol 1. is similar to the Ming Mvng Lung Phai of Tileswar Mohan, 2r1; IMG 0012 relates to the coming down to earth of various demigods, such as tang an mip sai phun nyoi nyoi ko lung ma 'and then, the rain god … also came down.' The ceremony of Um Pha and Sai Pha are the same but if it is within the family, it is called Sai Pha, but in a wider context it is called Um Pha. The MS up to fol 4v (IMG 0011) contains a list of different Gods and demigods that have come down to earth with Lengdon, to receive offerings. On fol4 v (image 0011) an Assamese note states that the manuscript had been taken by one Kokaideo (brother) and 'returned only yesterday and I have received it only today'

Description:
It contains a story about a Naga Messenger. folio 14 r, line 2, pi lak ni pvk san dvn sip it chu man mriu dv driu mai lai khau la men pu thi ('In the Lakni year Pvk san, in the eleventh month, his name was Mou Deodhai wrote'). Dated with the Lakni calendrical system. This refers to the repeating 60 year cycle (see Terwiel 1981, Morey 2015), which is repeated. Thus a manuscript dated Lakni Khut Mit, could be 1695-6, 1755-6 or 1815-6. (The exact alignment of Lakni years with the Gregorian Calendar varies one or two years by different calculations). Pi Nai Lak Ni Pvk San, Din Sip during the period of Halraid Sahab. The Pvk San year is 1814-15, but the mention of Halraid Sahab (presumably Mr Holyrood) suggests a date during the British period. The quality of the script however suggests it was copied before British times.We have not yet identified who is being referred to as Halraid.
